IRRIGATION SCHEMES RENOVATED FROM 2015-2017 : KILINOCHCHI DISTRICT 259/18
5. () ( ) ( () - . . ) (The Hon. (Dr.) Bandula Gunawardane on behalf of the Hon. R.M. Padma Udhayashantha Gunasekera) , , , - (1):
asked the Minister of Agriculture, Rural Economic Affairs, Livestock Development, Irrigation and Fisheries and Aquatic Resources Development:
(i) the minor, medium and major irrigation schemes renovated in Kilinochchi District in the years 2015, 2016 and 2017;
(ii) the estimated amount for each renovation work, separately;
(iii) whether tenders were called for the said renovation work;
(iv) if so, whether a list of names of the contractors who obtained those tenders will be submitted;
(v) the physical and financial progress of the renovation work of that contract with relevance to each of the aforesaid years;
(vi) whether the feasibility study, environmental and engineering reports relevant to that renovation work will be submitted;
(vii) whether tenders were called for the silt, soil or sand removed in renovation work; and
(viii) if so, whether a list of names of the contractors who obtained those tenders will be submitted?
(b) If not, why? ( ) (The Hon. Gayantha Karunatileka) , , , ,

. , ? . , . , . ; . " " . . . . . . . . . ... . . , "brain drain" . ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) , . ( ) (The Hon. Eran Wickramaratne) . ; - ; ; ; . . . I was studying overseas when the 1983 riots took place. I benefited from an overseas education. But, we - the

others and I - decided to come back. Life and education is not just about economic return. Since we were born into Sri lankan families and a Sri Lankan society, we have a duty to serve our families and our society. Remember, education is not just about yourself, but about the larger society. Sri Lanka needs you and you must return. This country's future depends on your contribution to the country. Therefore, all of us who have had the opportunity of studying overseas must contribute to Sri Lanka's future.

Hon. Chairman, between 2011 and 2014, Recurrent Expenditure was Rs. 68 billion. Between 2015 and 2018, it rose up to Rs. 124 billion. It is almost 83 per cent increase in Recurrent Expenditure alone. Capital expenditure, between 2011 and 2014, was Rs. 36 billion as against the expenditure of Rs. 77 billion between 2015 and 2018, which is an 114 per cent increase. So, overall, we have invested in the Higher Education sector 93 per cent more than the earlier regime's period. I mean, this is the difference in the investment in this sector.

Having said that, let me also very briefly tell you this. We have in our system 15 universities, 18 institutes and three campuses and in the Non-state sector 20 institutes have been granted degree-awarding status and several private institutions offer foreign degrees as well. Now, I am also glad to say this. Let me say this because this is a matter of pride for us. While the Eastern Province enjoyed the privilege of having two universities, Eastern University and South Eastern University, due to the conflict in the Northern Province, the Northern Province had only one university, that is the University of Jaffna. I am happy to announce today that steps have been taken to establish the second university at the location of the Vavuniya Campus titled University of Vanni and the Gazette will be released shortly.

Hon. Chairman, high quality university education is a magnet for nation building and we expect the universities to urgently address the issue of skills mismatch especially in the field of Humanities and Social Sciences, which constitute about 30 per cent of university intake. Universities have responded positively to this call

and with the AHEAD Project of the World Bank, all 15 State universities have won a competitive block grant of Rs. 100 million each for major restructuring of the curricula, syllabi, teaching - learning activities and evaluation systems. I will be handing over these awards on the 24th of March 2019.

Then, I must also talk about some of the changes that had taken place in some other areas, particularly, the quality assurance in higher education sector. A process-driven quality assurance system is already in existence in the State universities under the Quality Assurance Division of the University Grants Commission. A sustainable grading system in QA is in operation for State universities. However, we have recognized some deficiencies in the quality assurance and accreditation process in the higher education system in Sri Lanka, specially in Non-state higher education system. To address this issue which has a national impact, I am happy to inform you that a long awaited Bill to establish an Independent Qualify Assurance and Accreditation Commission for both State and Non-state higher education system is about to be submitted, next week I will submit the Cabinet paper, and we will bring the Bill to Parliament within the coming weeks. The necessary legal framework is already completed by the Legal Draftsman and the Office of the Attorney General. The Bill is expected to transform the quality of higher education landscape in Sri Lanka. In this context of quality assurance in higher education, I am also pleased to inform you that all global quality assurance agencies are going to be in Sri Lanka from 25th to 30th of March, 2019 to have their Biannual Global Conference in Quality Assurance in Higher Education. That is a matter of pride for all of us. We were able to bring a large number of delegates to attend these conferences. Then, I wish to deal with a few important aspects of challenges that we face in the higher education sector.
, , , 2015 350 2,450 2,150 , 2,150 2,400 . , 2,500 , 5,000 . . , bursaries . I would also like to deal with another important aspect.
( ) (The Hon. Bimal Rathnayake) , . . UGC . , . . ; , procedure , accreditation process . ( ) (The Hon.Rauff Hakeem) , . speech . , . .

Mr. Chairman, I know my time is up. But I just want to say a few words quickly about the issue of ragging in our university system. This is a serious problem in our university system. We have taken note of it. The University Grants Commission has been constantly discussing this matter with the Vice Chancellors in several universities. We understand that almost 1,987 students have left after entering universities and this is a very serious problem and most of them have left because of this inhumane ragging in the university system.

So, now we have adopted a zero-tolerance policy about ragging and we are taking effective action to prevent this. Of course, the entire power to prevent this happening is vested in the Vice Chancellors and the Councils of all those universities. But despite all the actions that have been taken by the UGC we still find that very inhumane methods are being used to carry on ragging in the universities. So, we are going on adopting a zero-tolerance policy. So, particularly with regard to ragging and sexual and gender-based violence in universities, I would like to say, providing safe and conducive environment in the universities is essential for development of higher education. There is a national outcry to curb the menace of ragging and sexual and gender-based violence in State universities. The UGC has taken a strategic lead to address gender inequalities and to prevent and minimize ragging and sexual and gender-based violence in State universities with the underlying principle, "zero-tolerance" to ragging and therefore, the major outcome in 2018 was the online ragging and sexual and gender-based violence redress mechanism at the UGC with a 24-hour hotline. We have seen increasing number of affected students and staff accessing the complaint system now and visiting the centre to make complaints confidentially with their parents and benefitting while perpetrators are receiving appropriate punishments.
Emergency safety mobile App for emergency situations including ragging and sexual and gender-based

violence was piloted and is being introduced. The UGC database on ragging is being linked to databases at the universities. Policy makers, planners, administrators and academia within the university system are being empowered to handle this. So, there are a variety of actions that we have taken. We are now conducting a major research study on the present status of incidents of ragging and sexual harassments in the State university system and strategies on combatting them at the system level to feed into policy decisions of the UGC including a high-powered taskforce to prevent and eliminate ragging with representatives from senior police officers, senior officers of the Attorney-Generals Department and university authorities responsible for student discipline.
So, this is a very important matter, Mr. Chairman. This is an issue that our Government will address with earnest seriousness that needs to be devoted to this aspect in our university system.
Thank you very much. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) , . 15. [..11.16] ( ) (The Hon. Mahinda Amaraweera) , . .

Hon. Speaker, will now take the Chair. , . , , . Whereupon THE HON. VELU KUMAR left the Chair, and THE HON. SPEAKER took the Chair. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) . ( ) (The Hon. Piyal Nishantha De Silva) . , . . .

. , . , . ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) . , . [6.41p.m.] ( , ) ( - , ) (The Hon. Rauff Hakeem - Minister of City Planning, Water Supply and Higher Education) Hon. Chairman, let me be very brief since time is limited. In the morning, I dealt with the Higher Education sector. Now, I have to say a few words on the Water Supply and City Planning sector.

In all, the National Water Supply and Drainage Board has completed 16 water projects and 38 projects are ongoing. Then, in the pipeline, we have another 30 odd projects. So, altogether, this amounts to Rs.1,192 billion worth of projects ongoing, completed as well as those in the pipeline, which have received some kind of approval to proceed. This will bring in almost another 2,390,367 connections to the Water Supply and Drainage Board.

We have, in our Investment Plan, various projects, which I have no time to describe here. But, I would like to briefly deal with the situation relating to the non-revenue water as far as the Water Supply and Drainage Board is concerned, because that has been one of the issues which always draws a lot of criticism. Islandwide, we have brought down the non-revenue water from 27 per cent to 24 per cent. In Colombo, it has come down to almost 40 per cent. This issue is of some concern. Therefore, we are working towards improving the situation.

I must also say something about the criticism relating to employment in the Water Supply and Drainage Board. Sir, we have an approved cadre of 11,073 though the existing cadre is only 10,185. We have had, in the past, 4.31 persons being employed per thousand connections, which was almost 5.19 persons per thousand connections in 2015. So, after I took over, the ratio of employees per thousand connections has come down drastically. This is an issue that, sometimes, is always misunderstood saying that we have been employing more than what is necessary. But, we are moving towards a situation where these will be brought under control.
In the meantime, it is very regrettable that the tariff has not been revised. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) Hon. Minister, you have another two minutes.
( ) (The Hon.Rauff Hakeem)Sir, I will finish within three minutes because I have to reply to some of the Hon. Members who have raised their matters.

Particularly, the Hon. Kaveendiran Kodeeswaran brought certain allegations against the Ministry saying that we have been only serving certain communities and that the Tamil community has been neglected by the City Planning Division of my Ministry. I must say that we have spent almost Rs. 566 million in the Tamil areas during the last two years. In Batticaloa, in Tamil areas of the Town alone, we have spent Rs. 200 million. Even in his Ampara District, on work carried out in Navithanvali, Saraswathi Vidyalaya, Navithanvali Road, Thambinayagapuram, Clinic Centre in Senakudiyiruppu, on improvment of Beach Road in Pandiuruppu and Malwatte Road, we have spent a lot of money. Then, he spoke about street lamps being installed only in non-Tamil areas.

I must say that the installation of street lights from Thalavatuvan Junction to Wesley High School Junction, Kalmunai has been done through my Ministry. So, these are all baseless allegations. We have spent almost Rs. 560 million in the Tamil areas. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) Hon. Minister, I am sorry to interrupt you, but you have almost exhausted your time. ( ) (The Hon.Rauff Hakeem) Sir, there are several other questions, particularly relating to water supply in the Tamil areas. I must say that we have taken action to implement a project at the cost of Rs. 5.5 billion to cover certain Tamil areas which have been left out in the Ampara District: Thirukkovil DS Division, Navithanveli Central Camp, Panankadu, Kannakipuram, Alayadivembu areas, Aligambay and Neeththai in Alayadiwembu Division. That contract had been awarded and now, the procurement is proceeding. So, I think, within the course of this year, we will start work on that and those grievances will be met. Similarly, the issue of the Unnichchi Tank has, once again, been raised by the Hon. Seeniththamby Yoheswaran and other Hon. Members. We will be looking into that and giving whatever relief possible.
In the meantime, some other issues have been raised by other Hon. Members, to whom I need to reply. But, since time is limited, let me write to them and clarify all their questions.
Thank you, Sir. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) Thank you very much, Hon. Minister, for your understanding. , .

( ) (The Hon. Kanchana Wijesekera) Sir, I rise to a point of Order. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) What is the point of Order? Time is limited. ( ) (The Hon. Kanchana Wijesekera) Sir, I want to ask one question. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) No, you cannot ask questions at this time. ( ) (The Hon. Kanchana Wijesekera) Just one clarification. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) No clarifications can be allowed. We have to stop at that. ( ) (The Hon.Rauff Hakeem) If I say this very quickly, Sir, the Hon. Kanchana Wijesekera said that we are not giving water connections. He said that our officials are saying, We cannot give connections until 2025. In fact, the Matara Water Supply Project - Stage IV will be completed by April, 2020 and the following areas will be covered: Malimbada, Weligama, Welipitiya, Athuraliya, Thihagoda, Devinuwara, Dickwella, Kirinda Puhulwella, Kamburupitiya and Beliatta also. Rs. 18 billion is being spent on this and the population that will be covered is 280,000 with a 24-hour connection to the existing people. It is a very large project that we are implementing. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) That is fine. Thank you very much. ( ) (The Hon.Rauff Hakeem) I will write to you, Hon. Member. ( ) (The Hon. Chairman) Next, the Hon. Minister of Education. ( ) (The Hon. Akila Viraj Kariyawasam) , ?
( ) (The Hon. Chairman) . [.. 6.48] ( ) (The Hon. Akila Viraj Kariyawasam) , .

HEAD 214.- UNIVERSITY GRANTS COMMISSION Programme 02.- Development Activities - Recurrent Expenditure, Rs. 45,625,000,000 Question, "That the sum of Rs. 45,625,000,000, for Head 214, Programme 02, Recurrent Expenditure, be inserted in the Schedule" put and agreed to. Head 214, Programme 02, Recurrent Expenditure, ordered to stand part of the Schedule.

Programme 02.- Development Activities - Capital Expenditure, Rs. 16,100,000,000 Question, "That the sum of Rs. 16,100,000,000, for Head 214, Programme 02, Capital Expenditure, be inserted in the Schedule" put and agreed to. Head 214, Programme 02, Capital Expenditure, ordered to stand part of the Schedule. HEAD 332.- DEPARTMENT OF NATIONAL COMMUNITY WATER SUPPLY Programme 01.- Operational Activities - Recurrent Expenditure, Rs. 148,000,000 Question, "That the sum of Rs. 148,000,000, for Head 332, Programme 01, Recurrent Expenditure, be inserted in the Schedule" put and agreed to. Head 332, Programme 01, Recurrent Expenditure, ordered to stand part of the Schedule. Programme 01.- Operational Activities - Capital Expenditure, Rs. 206,000,000 Question, "That the sum of Rs. 206,000,000, for Head 332, Programme 01, Capital Expenditure, be inserted in the Schedule" put and agreed to. Head 332, Programme 01, Capital Expenditure, ordered to stand part of the Schedule. ( ) (The Hon. Lakshman Kiriella) " , " . , . . Question put, and agreed to.
